query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Various methods are available for controlling disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms. Cleaner wrasse fish can be used as natural control agents against sea lice, with one study finding they were as effective as chemical treatments, though another study found them ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks. Probiotics and immunostimulants in feed can increase survival when salmon are exposed to disease-causing bacteria, while vaccination programs have shown higher survival rates against diseases including Aeromonas salmonicida, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia. Fallowing systems, where cages are left empty between production cycles, have shown mixed results with one study recording lower lice numbers in Scotland but another finding no difference in amoebic gill disease mortality in Australia. Freshwater bathing can reduce amoebae on salmon gills for up to 10 days, though one study found similar levels between treated and untreated salmon. Breeding programs for disease resistance traits have increased survival levels when salmon families were bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis. Additionally, dietary changes including plant-based proteins can reduce lice infection by 28%, and beta-glucans can provide an additional 28% reduction in lice infection levels.

The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary:
Based on studies conducted in Norway, plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal show different effects on Atlantic salmon growth rates. Plant-based proteins generally resulted in decreased growth rates in Atlantic salmon across four replicated, controlled studies (action ID 924). Additionally, plant-based protein diets led to reduced final body weights in four studies and showed mixed results on feeding efficiency, with two studies showing lowered levels and one showing increased efficiency (action ID 924). Two studies also found reduced digestibility of feed components when plant proteins were used compared to fish meal (action ID 924).

In contrast, bacterial protein alternatives showed more promising results. Two replicated, controlled studies in Norway found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets containing up to 25% bacterial protein compared to 100% fish meal diets (action ID 918). Growth rates only decreased when bacterial protein reached 50% of the diet. Another Norwegian study found higher growth rates in salmon fed diets containing 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to the control or a 4.5% bacterial protein diet (action ID 918).

Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from the action documents, several interventions demonstrate effectiveness for increasing survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease: Vaccinations show consistent positive results across multiple controlled studies in Iceland, Norway, Australia, and Canada, with higher survival rates reported for salmon vaccinated against Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia. Breeding for resistance traits proves effective, as demonstrated by a controlled study in Norway showing increased survival in salmon bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to those bred for low resistance. Aerobic training interventions, particularly interval training, resulted in higher survival rates for salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis in a Norwegian study. The use of probiotics and immunostimulants shows promise, with a Scottish study reporting increased survival in salmon fed probiotics before exposure to disease-causing bacteria, while a Norwegian study found beta-glucans reduced lice infection by 28% and mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function. Freshwater bathing provides mixed results for amoebic gill disease, with one Australian study showing temporary reduction in amoebae on gills persisting up to 10 days, while another found no significant difference between treated and untreated salmon. A study in Scotland also found lower lice numbers on salmon in cages using a fallowing system.

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Studies from Norway and Scotland show that using plant-based proteins in salmon feed has mixed effects. Six studies found decreased growth rates, while three studies found similar growth rates between plant-based and fish meal diets. Four studies reported reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based proteins, while two studies found similar weights. Feeding efficiency was found to be both lowered and increased in different Norwegian studies, with Canadian and Scottish studies showing similar efficiency across diet types. Digestibility was found to be lower in some studies but similar in others across both regions. Survival rates and appetite were not affected, but morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based proteins. Fish condition increased in one study but decreased in two others when using plant-based protein diets.

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Several non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms have been documented. Biological control using cleaner wrasse fish shows mixed results - studies in Ireland found that corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments for controlling lice infestation, while rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks (Action 738). Lighting management is another approach, with a replicated controlled study in Norway showing that salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting had lower numbers of lice, and more intense artificial light resulted in higher lice numbers (Action 741). Dietary modifications using probiotics and immunostimulants have shown promise - salmon fed a probiotic had increased survival when exposed to disease-causing bacteria (Action 732), and a Norwegian study found that feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced lice infection by 28%, while adding beta-glucans decreased infection by a further 28% (Action 732). Fallowing systems, where cages are left empty between production cycles, have shown mixed results - one study in Scotland found lower lice numbers with fallowing, while an Australian study found no difference in disease mortality (Action 1026).

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents found, krill meal as a fishmeal alternative resulted in similar final weight gain and feed conversion ratios compared to fishmeal diets in Atlantic salmon, with better growth rates when krill were de-shelled rather than left whole (Action 916). Yeast protein from Yarrowia lipolytica showed no differences in weight compared to fishmeal controls (Action 920). Animal protein alternatives showed mixed results - one study found no difference in oxygen consumption or swimming speed between salmon fed anchovy oil versus alternative lipid sources, while another Scottish study showed fish fed fishmeal weighed more than those fed diets with alternative proteins (Action 922).

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: Studies in Norway have examined various alternative feed components for Atlantic salmon diets with mixed results. For genetically modified alternatives, three controlled studies found no difference in growth rate between salmon fed GM versus non-GM soybeans. Bacterial protein showed mixed effects - two studies found similar growth rates when replacing up to 25% of fish meal with bacterial protein, but reduced growth at 50% replacement, while another study reported higher growth rates with 18-36% bacterial protein inclusion. Yeast-based protein (Yarrowia lipolytica) showed no difference in weight compared to fishmeal diets in one experiment. Plant-based protein sources demonstrated consistently negative effects, with six studies showing decreased growth rates, reduced final body weights, lower feeding efficiency, and altered intestinal morphology, though two studies found unaffected survival rates and appetite. Plant-based oils showed more positive results, with three studies finding similar or higher growth rates compared to fish oil, maintained body weights, and reduced dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyl levels in salmon flesh, though fatty acid profiles reflected the oil source. Krill meal showed promise with similar final weight gain and feed conversion ratios to fish meal diets. Supplements like taurine showed no effect on weight gain. Reducing fish meal levels maintained similar final weights across low, medium, and high fish meal diets.

query: What are the effects of altering the physical environment of salmon cages, such as their size or lighting, on salmon health in aquaculture?
relevant_summary: The evidence from action documents shows that altering cage size and lighting conditions can significantly affect salmon health in aquaculture systems. One replicated study in Australia (action ID 742) found that salmon kept in larger cages had lower levels of amoebic gill disease compared to those in smaller cages. Similarly, a replicated controlled study in Norway (action ID 741) demonstrated that lighting intensity affected parasite loads, with salmon kept under low intensity artificial light or natural lighting having lower numbers of lice compared to those under more intense artificial lighting, where higher light intensity correlated with increased lice numbers.

query: How do different non-chemical water-based treatments, such as fallowing and freshwater bathing, compare in their reported effectiveness for specific diseases in salmon?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, freshwater bathing and fallowing show mixed effectiveness for treating salmon diseases. For freshwater bathing, two studies in Australia found mixed evidence for reducing amoebic gill disease - one study found a reduction in numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after bathing (action 739), while one replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in the gills of treated and untreated salmon (action 739). For fallowing, a study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system (action 1026), but another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used (action 1026).

query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary: Several dietary alternatives to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight. Krill meal was found to result in similar final weight gain and feed conversion ratios compared to fish meal diets in two replicated studies in Norway (Action 916). Yeast protein from Yarrowia lipolytica showed no differences in weight compared to control fishmeal diets in a controlled experiment in Norway (Action 920). Bacterial protein at levels up to 25% replacement of fish meal resulted in similar growth rates compared to 100% fish meal diets in two replicated, controlled studies in Norway (Action 918). Plant-based oils as alternatives to fish oil showed similar or even higher growth rates in three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway, with similar average final body weights between salmon fed both fish oil and vegetable oil diets (Action 926). Supplements including phytase and phosphate showed no difference in weight gain in a controlled, replicated study in Australia, and taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain in a controlled, replicated study in Norway (Action 930). Genetically modified soybeans showed no difference in growth rate compared to non-GM soybeans in three controlled, replicated studies in Norway (Action 928).

query: What is the evidence that integrated aquaculture systems or constructing artificial reefs can mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms?
relevant_summary: There is limited but promising evidence for integrated aquaculture systems mitigating salmon farm impacts, with one Canadian study demonstrating that blue mussels absorbed waste from salmon farms. Additional evidence shows enhanced growth of scallops and algae when placed adjacent to fish farms. However, results are mixed, with some studies finding no evidence of shellfish consuming fish farm waste. For artificial reefs, the evidence is very limited - while two controlled studies examined artificial reefs placed near aquaculture operations to benefit from nutrient run-offs, neither showed significant differences in invertebrate communities compared to control sites. No studies were found evaluating artificial reefs designed specifically as biofilters for salmon farms.

query: How do physical interventions like aerobic training and altering cage size affect the health and survival of farmed Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary:
Aerobic training has been shown to significantly improve survival rates in Atlantic salmon. A randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if they had undergone aerobic training, with interval training being more effective than continuous training.

Cage size also affects Atlantic salmon health outcomes. A replicated study in Australia recorded lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon kept within larger compared to smaller cages.

query: What are the observed effects on salmon growth and flesh quality when replacing fish oil with plant-based or other animal-based oils in their diet?
relevant_summary:
Studies have found mixed effects on salmon growth when replacing fish oil with plant-based oils. Three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway found similar growth rates in salmon fed diets containing fish oil versus vegetable oil, while one study found higher growth rates in fish fed vegetable oil diets. One replicated, controlled study found salmon growth rates were both lower and higher in vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets, depending on family genetics.

Regarding flesh quality, three replicated studies (two controlled) in Norway and Scotland found that the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source within diets. A replicated, controlled study found that salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls within flesh compared to diets containing fish oil.

One study in Norway found no differences in salmon flesh quality (gaping, texture, and liquid holding capacity) between fish fed vegetable oil- and fish oil-based diets, though pigment concentration was lower in vegetable oil diets. Studies also noted some physiological differences, with one replicate Norwegian study finding that salmon fed vegetable oil diets had high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein compared to fish oil diets.

One controlled Canadian study on alternative animal-based lipid sources found no difference in oxygen consumption or swimming speed of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing anchovy oil or alternative lipid sources.

query: What is the evidence regarding the effect of using genetically modified ingredients or dietary supplements on the growth of Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary: Three controlled, replicated studies in Norway found no difference in growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either GM or non-GM soybeans (Action ID 928). One randomized, replicated, controlled study found no differences in histology of fish fed GM or non-GM soybeans (Action ID 928). Regarding dietary supplements, studies showed mixed results: a controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain with phytase and phosphate supplementation, while another found greater final weights with phytase supplementation (Action ID 930). A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain with taurine supplementation (Action ID 930). Plant-based protein sources generally led to decreased growth rates compared to fish meal diets, with six studies showing decreased growth and three showing similar growth rates (Action ID 924).

query: What are the documented outcomes of using genetic selection or manipulation, such as breeding for disease resistance or inducing triploidy, in salmon aquaculture?
relevant_summary: Documented outcomes from genetic selection and manipulation in salmon aquaculture include: Breeding for disease resistance showed increased survival levels in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis when families were bred for high resistance compared to those bred for low resistance (Action ID: 735). Triploid salmon demonstrated reduced return of stock but maintained similar weight, length and condition compared with diploid salmon (Action ID: 939). Genetically modified soybeans used in salmon feed showed no difference in growth rate between Atlantic salmon fed diets containing GM versus non-GM soybeans, according to three controlled, replicated studies (Action ID: 928). Additionally, one randomised, replicated, controlled study found no differences in histology of fish fed diets containing GM versus non-GM soybeans (Action ID: 928).

query: What are the comparative effects on Atlantic salmon weight when substituting fishmeal with krill, yeast, or other animal-based proteins?
relevant_summary: Based on the available research evidence, krill meal appears to maintain similar weight gain in Atlantic salmon compared to fishmeal diets. Two studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed fish meal only diets versus krill meal substitutes, with better growth rates achieved when krill were de-shelled rather than left whole. Yeast protein (specifically Yarrowia lipolytica) showed no difference in weight compared to control fishmeal diets according to one replicated, controlled experiment in Norway. Animal-based proteins showed mixed results, with one controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland demonstrating that salmon fed fishmeal diets weighed more than those fed diets with alternative animal proteins. Bacterial protein demonstrated mixed effects on growth, with studies showing similar growth rates at up to 25% replacement of fishmeal, but reduced growth at 50% replacement. However, some studies reported higher growth rates at 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion compared to control.

query: What actions are available to manage the waste products, such as excess nutrients and sludge, from salmon aquaculture operations?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several actions can be used to manage waste products from salmon aquaculture operations. Integrated aquaculture systems (Action 932) have shown effectiveness where blue mussels can absorb waste from salmon farms, and scallops and algae placed adjacent to fish farms demonstrate enhanced growth. For sludge management specifically, drying sludge in beds (Action 943) has been shown in replicated trials in Canada to effectively remove phosphorus from freshwater fish farm sludge. Other potential approaches include establishing aquaculture facilities specifically to extract nutrients from run-offs (Action 2883), switching to land-based aquaculture systems (Action 3583) which may provide better waste containment, and cleaning wastewater before environmental release (Action 3142). Additional management strategies include minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems (Action 2744), modifying aquaculture practices to reduce pollution (Action 3172), and introducing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems (Action 2876). Using species from multiple trophic levels in aquaculture systems (Action 2195) can also potentially help manage waste through natural biological processes.

query: What is the evidence from Australian studies on the effectiveness of different husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon?
relevant_summary: Australian studies on husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon show mixed results. Freshwater bathing had mixed effectiveness, with one study finding a reduction in amoebae numbers on salmon gills lasting up to 10 days, while another replicated, controlled study found similar amoebae levels in treated and untreated salmon. Cage size was found to be significant, with a replicated Australian study recording lower levels of Amoebic Gill Disease in salmon kept in larger compared to smaller cages. Fallowing systems showed no evidence of effectiveness, with an Australian study finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where fallowing had been used compared to those without fallowing.

query: Beyond growth rates, what other biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with krill or plant-based proteins instead of fish meal?
relevant_summary: Beyond growth rates, several biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with alternative protein sources. For plant-based proteins, studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected, but morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomized, replicated, controlled studies (Action ID 924). Digestibility of feed components was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal (Action ID 924). The condition of salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one study but reduced in two other studies (Action ID 924). Two replicated studies found lowered levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets (Action ID 924). For krill meal diets, the number of aerobic bacteria in the hindgut of salmon was higher and the composition of bacterial flora was different compared to fish meal diets (Action ID 916). Additionally, when salmon were fed diets containing 28% plant-based protein combined with beta-glucans, lice infection levels decreased by 28% compared to controls (Action ID 732).

query: What non-chemical methods can be used to manage pests and biofouling on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Non-chemical pest management methods for salmon farms include using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents, with studies showing mixed effectiveness for sea lice control (Action ID: 738). Fallowing systems can reduce parasites and disease, with one Scottish study recording lower lice numbers on salmon in cages using fallowing (Action ID: 1026). Bird pest management employs acoustic deterrents like distress calls, visual deterrents such as scarecrows, and trained raptors, though birds often become habituated to these methods (Action ID: 244). Specific biofouling management actions include preventing biofouling organism attachment and removing biofouling organisms, though no studies have evaluated their effectiveness yet (Action IDs: 2162, 2163). Additional preventive measures involve sourcing disease-free juveniles and implementing regular inspections to avoid introducing problematic species (Action IDs: 2159, 2157).

One before-and-after study from Israel found that the population of pygmy cormorants in the area increased after birds were scared away from fish farms, possibly due to lower persecution.
One of two studies that examined fish stocks found that fewer fish were taken from a farm when heron distress calls were played. The other study, a literature review, found no evidence for the effects of scaring birds on fish stocks.
Two replicated studies from Belgium and Australia found that using foot patrols to disturb birds from fish farms did not reduce the number of birds present or fish consumption.
Ten of eleven studies from across the world, three controlled, found evidence that playing distress calls or using other acoustic deterrents (some with flashes of light) reduced the number of birds at fish farms, or changed bird behaviours. One of these involved underwater broadcasting. One study found effects were only temporary and five found that birds became habituated to noises. Four studies, one replicated and controlled, two before-and-after, found that acoustic deterrents were not effective in scaring birds.
Five of seven studies, one controlled, found evidence that visual deterrents (including inflatable ‘Scarey Man’ scarecrows) reduced the number of birds at fish farms. Three found evidence for habituation to deterrents and three studies found no evidence that visual deterrents were effective. 
Two studies examined other deterrents, finding that trained raptors were effective but that the effects of helicopters and ultra-light aircraft were either inconclusive or very temporary."
}

query: What factors influence the success of non-pesticide methods for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Studies show mixed effectiveness of non-pesticide sea lice control methods. Cleaner wrasse effectiveness varies by species - corkwing and goldskinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective (Action ID: 738). Lighting intensity affects lice numbers, with lower intensity artificial light or natural lighting resulting in fewer lice compared to high intensity artificial light (Action ID: 741). Dietary modifications can reduce lice infection - feeding salmon a diet with 28% plant-based protein reduced lice by 28%, and adding beta-glucans decreased infection by a further 28% (Action ID: 732). Fallowing systems showed mixed results, with one study recording lower lice numbers in Scotland but another finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in Australia (Action ID: 1026). Vaccinations and breeding for disease resistance improved survival against various pathogens but specific effects on sea lice control were not documented (Action IDs: 733, 735).

query: In Norway, how do different plant-based feed alternatives, such as vegetable oils versus plant proteins, affect salmon growth and body composition?
relevant_summary:
Studies in Norway comparing plant-based feed alternatives for salmon show distinct effects between vegetable oils and plant proteins. For vegetable oil alternatives, three replicated studies found similar or higher growth rates in salmon fed vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets. However, the fatty acid profile of salmon flesh reflected the oil source, with vegetable oil diets resulting in high liver lipid and low plasma lipoprotein levels and lower concentrations of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to fish oil diets. Salmon fed vegetable oil-based diets also had lower concentrations of dioxin and polychlorinated biphenyls in their flesh.

For plant protein alternatives, six studies found that inclusion of plant-based proteins led to decreased growth rates in salmon, with four studies showing reduced final body weights compared to fish meal-based diets. Digestibility of feed components was lower with plant proteins, and morphology of the distal intestine was altered in salmon fed plant-based protein diets. However, survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant-based protein diets.

Both alternatives maintained similar feeding efficiency levels in most studies, though some studies showed either lowered or increased feeding efficiency with plant proteins depending on the specific study conditions.

query: What are the documented effects, both positive and negative, of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: Based on evidence from action documents, replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets has shown mixed effects. Negative effects include: decreased growth rates (6 studies from Norway, Scotland, USA), reduced final body weights (4 studies from Norway, Scotland), lowered feeding efficiency (2 studies from Norway), reduced digestibility of feed components (2 studies), altered intestinal morphology (2 studies), and reduced condition (2 studies). Positive or neutral effects include: similar growth rates (3 studies from Norway, Canada, Scotland), similar final body weights (2 studies from Norway), similar feeding efficiency (2 studies from Canada, Scotland), similar digestibility levels (2 studies), unaffected survival rates and appetite (2 studies), and increased condition in one study. Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weights in salmon fed diets containing low, medium or high levels of fish meal.

query: What does the evidence say about using probiotics, immunostimulants, or specific training to improve salmon survival against diseases?
relevant_summary: The evidence shows that probiotics and immunostimulants can improve salmon survival against diseases. A replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28-day period compared with controls (Action 732). The same research found that adding beta-glucans to salmon diet decreased lice infection levels by 28% compared with controls, and mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis (Action 732). Regarding training methods, a randomized, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival rates in salmon exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis if they had undergone aerobic training, with interval training being more effective than continuous training (Action 740). Vaccinations were also shown to be effective, with multiple controlled studies demonstrating higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated controls when exposed to various bacterial diseases (Action 733).

query: Based on studies in Australia, which husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming?
relevant_summary: Based on studies in Australia, several salmon farming disease management practices have shown mixed or limited success. Studies on freshwater bathing to reduce amoebic gill disease found mixed results - while one study reported a reduction in gill amoebae persisting up to 10 days after bathing, controlled studies found similar levels of amoebae in treated and untreated salmon (Action ID: 739). Fallowing practices also showed mixed results, with one study finding no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages using fallowing systems, though fallowing did improve sediment community conditions (Action ID: 1026, 1027). Vaccination studies showed positive results internationally, but the evidence base for Australia's salmon farming was not specifically detailed as showing different outcomes from other regions (Action ID: 733).
